description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Number of country diagnostics carried out to inform policy options on national response to globally agreed development agenda, including with analysis of sustainability and risk resilience
Number of new public-private partnership (PPP) mechanisms that provide innovative solutions for development
number of pilots and demonstration projects initiated by national partners
number of pilots and demonstration projects scaled up by national partners

The project provides capacity development to the Bank of Sierra Leone staff on financial management skills and has over the years provided both technical support and capacity building of the PPP unit to analyse, tender and negotiate PPP transactions.
capital of a political entity
Number of technical support, methodology document prepared and PPP investment deals supported Number of BoSL Research staff trained and number and type of support provided

comment.narrative: Initial legal and institutional framework in place; capacity for soliciting small scale service delivery and local content centered PPP investments is weak and scattered; Limited financial services to more than half of the population

1. a) at least 2 PPP Agreements signed/reviewed b) Medium - Improved technical capaicty to carry out work of PPP unit
2. Training on inclusive financial policy analysis and benchmarking

The Unit has completed implementation on all activities viz PPP-specific training for staff, procurement of IT network configuration service, upgrade of the PPP Web Site content to improve sensitization on procurement process and best practices, support to PPP Unit capacity with office equipment and stationary and regional training workshop on PPP/PPCP fundamentals and benefits

Conduct nationwide training on inclusive financial policy analysis and services
Train and sensitize MDA personnel and Local Government Authorities on infrastructure PPs and social impact projects and public relations, including media outreach and printing of PPP testimonials, brochures, banners and flyers

1. PPP Unit staff are fully capacitated to analyze tender, negotiate PPP transactions and provide technical support to specific PPP transactions including the Public Private and Community Partnership (PPCP) in waste management launched in Makeni city council. 2. 50 Local council Staff in Kono, Bo and Makeni and relevant MDAs received roll out training on the Makeni City Council revenue mobilization drive using the Public, Private and Community participation approach. This has increased the revenue base in the target councils specifically in Bo and Kono city councils.

description.narrative: Credible elections for Parliamentary seats and support to the Parliament has provided an opportunity for MPs effectively realize their mandates towards the peaceful resolution of ethnic differences and lessening of traditional tribal animosities.

To strengthen capacity of parliament to effectively carry out its legislative, representative and oversight functions as well as perform its central role of ensuring reconciliation and securing lasting peace fin Sierra Leone.
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

comment.narrative: - Develop concept parliament budget office. - 15 staff of parliament benefit from specialised training on bill drafting. - Establish Audio visual unit and record at least 10 radio programs. - Staff/MPs conduct outreach to 3 schools/education institutions. - Strengthen the capacity of PACO in coordinating the work of parliament. - At least 5 gender issues taken up by the Committee on Social Welfare.

- Concept on the Parliament Budget Office developed and shared. - Conducted Peer learning visit by key Parliament staff and a few MP's to the Parliament of Ghana and Uganda. - Specialised training (Workshop on essentials of Bill drafting) on Legislative process within Parliament held for key staff. - Legislative Department reaches out to schools with presentations, for the first time, on actual workings of Parliament working. - PACO effectively managed donor support in Parliament- UNDP, UNICEF, ACBF, CPA and other stakeholders inclduing the new Westminster Foundation for Democracy (WFD).

1.Ensure parliament sets up the Parliamentary Committee on SDGs. 2.Set up the Parliamentary Budget Office (PBO) and recruit 1 Economist in the Parliamentary service. 3.Ensure PBO staff and the 3 Finance Committees benefit from specialized technical support from an African Parliament. 4.Support Parliament to participate/conduct international parliamentary events. 5.Support Parliamentary outreach to schools 6.Document legacy/achievements and challenges of current Parliament (2012-17).

1.Technical advisory support to the Parliament leadership ensured the buy-in for setting up of the Parliamentary Committee on SDGs. An inaugural meeting with all the key stakeholders and Ministry of Finance and Economic Development was held explaining the key steps taken by the government in generating the national SDG framework of indicators and targets and the linkages with Agenda for Prosperity. The Committee was supported through a workshop on SDGs and the Agenda 2063. Further, a workshop was held for the Parliamentary Committee Clerks to introduce them to the targets and indicators of the SDGs and the forward planning for integrating the agreed national framework on SDGs into the oversight work of the Committees. In July, a woman MP, the IPU Rapporteur, was supported to attend the High Level meeting on SDGs at New York.
2.In continuation of UNDP support in 2016 wherein Clerk of Parliament and senior MPs and staff were supported to go for peer learning visits to the Parliaments of Ghana and Uganda, in this year, discussions were held by the Parliamentary Service Commission and Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MOFED), the reports with recommendation were laid on the Table and Parliament resolved to set up the Parliamentary Budget Office (PBO) in the Parliamentary Service. UNDP then recruited the economist to lead the office.
3.As per the agreement with the Parliament of Uganda, two key experts from the PBO in Uganda were supported to visit Sierra Leone to brief the key staff, including the Committee Clerks, Directors, Members of the Finance Committees and the senior MPs on the establishment of the PBO, its strategic relevance, likely challenges and way forward. The knowledge sharing was much appreciated and in tandem with their visit a workshop was held to explain the financial process, the Public Financial Management Act, 2016 and related issues of budget process in Sierra Leone. The South-South Cooperation exercise is proving to be of use

description.narrative: The project aimed at strengthening the policy framework and institutional arrangements for managing natural resources and addressing land tenure, climate change, disaster, and environmental management.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

? National Training Action plan developed and validated ? Institutions, Mechanisms and Capacities strengthened for rapid responses to national disasters at all levels ? Review and integrate Guidelines on International Disaster Relief into national DRM policy and action plan ? Conduct Risks and vulnerability profiles for selected districts

comment.narrative: Disaster preparedness, risk reduction and response strategies are integrated into national development planning

1. Development and endorsement of the Core Minerals Policy based on the African Mining version 2. Development of a 5-Year Roll Out Plan for Core Minerals Policy 3. Finalisation and publication of the State of Environment Report 4. Capacity building for centralised GIS database management and information dissemination 5. Facilitation of a dialogue platform for natural resource governance 6. Training of NPAA staff on forest landscape restoration 7. Acquire high resolution satellite images for nation-wide assessment of forest cover. 8. Nationwide popularisation on relevant provisions of the Disaster Risk Management Policy 9. Facilitate the strengthening of effective DRM response mechanisms

1. Development and endorsement of the Core Minerals Policy based on the African Mining version 2. Development of a 5-Year Roll Out Plan for Core Minerals Policy - A 5-year Roll Out Plan for Core Minerals Policy has been developed and validated which will serve as the road map for the implementation of strategies outline in the core minerals policy 3. Finalisation and publication of the State of Environment Report - The inaugural State of Environment Report has been published and launched by the EPA with support from the UNDP. The UNDP supported Coastal Sensitivity Maps was also officially launched. 4. Capacity building for centralised GIS database management and information dissemination - Equipment has been procured and installed to enhance the overall capacity of the EPA with the GIS database management and information dissemination. Support was also provided to the EPA Kono Office on GIS mapping for environmental governance
5. Facilitation of a dialogue platform for natural resource governance - One meeting was held with key environmental CSOs and NGOS and the Academic to facilitate the establishment of a platform for catalytic civil society engagements on natural resources management issues in Sierra Leone 6. Training of NPAA staff on forest landscape restoration - A staff of the NPAA has been trained by the US Forestry Department/Office of International Programs on forest landscape restoration. The NPAA staff is now a trainer for other foresters and park management officers and this training has been put into use with the establishment of new protected areas in the country. 7. Acquire high resolution satellite images for nation-wide assessment of forest cover. - High resolution satellite images have been procured from NASA for the NPAA for nation-wide assessment of forest cover which covers a forest cover of the country at 35%.
8. Nationwide popularisation on relevant provisions of the Disaster Risk Management Policy - Various awareness raising activities

1. Popularization and launch of the National Land Policy Roll, Sierra Leone Minerals Policy and NRC benchmarking report, National Disaster Risk Management Policy 2. Capacity enhancement and technical support to Ministry of Mines and Mineral Resources and the newly established Policy Directorate in order to implement the 5-year Strategic Plan 3. Alignment of the NDC implementation with ongoing initiatives 4. Reform/Revision of the present current Climate Change Policy and drafting of the Climate Change Bill and Associated Strategic Plan 5. Conduct of the Village to Village Environment Education and Biodiversity and Conservation Education Strategy 6. Development of a legal, policy and regulatory support for revenue sharing within the PA communities 7. Review / Reform the National Hazard Profile 8. Training on technical skills on data collection, interpretation and analyzing of DRM data

1. Land policy as been launched and popularized in nine districts through workshops in regional head quarter towns. Further popularization will be done through radio jingles, drama and posters with different messages 2. The policy unit of the Ministry of Mines has been rehabilitated and equipped to serve as a resource center for information sharing and the website for the Ministry of Mines and Natural Resources is currently under development. 3. The NDC alignment report in the various sectors has been prepared and uploaded for reference. 4.The Climate Change policy and strategic plan has been approved by cabinet. 5. With funding provided to the EPA-SL embark on series of village to village sensitization in a number of districts. report uploaded. 6. A draft regulatory framework for the sharing of revenue within the Protected Area communities has been developed. 7. The Sierra Leone hazard Profile has been reviewed and a comprehensive report prepared. It will be launched by the President in the second week of January 8. Disaster management committees have been trained on data collection skills, interpretation and analysis of Disaster Risk Management data.

This project supports the institutional reform and capacity of national and local institutions engaged in decentralized good governance and empowers local councils to enhance local economic development.

description.narrative: Level and number of implementation activities; finalized LoCASL Strategic Plan and its implementation; contributions of Chiefdoms to LG planning, and local resource mobilization

comment.narrative: A partial Implementation Strategy has been finalized, LoCASL has a functional Secretariat and a draft Strategic Plan, the Chiefdom Policy has been disseminated and Chiefdom Administrative Clerks trained in FM and Administration

Develop Local Economic Development (LED) Policy and Action Plan, provide capacity building support to Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs),Support Local Councils (LCs) to review their development plans to include LED component
LED and Rural Development policies developed, Capacities of 30 SMEs developed through training, mentoring and grants and 3 (three) LCs development plans reviewed to include the LED components.

1.Conduct LGED final evaluation 2. Support 50 women-led SMEs in Kailahun and Kambia districts to engage in adult literacy programme for effective book keeping and financial management 3. Conduct validation of the draft Rural Development Coordination policy in four regions 4. Conduct citizens/local council engagement forum in 4 pilot local council areas to enhance linkages of local government and citizens for sustainable development and basic service delivery. 5. Conduct Paramount Chiefs Retreat to share Rwanda experience on local governance and responsibilities of effective devolution of government functions.

1. LGED final evaluation report prepared and endorsed and will guide the preparation of LGED new project document 2. Support 50- women - led SMEs in Kailahun and Kambia districts through adult literacy programme to enhance effective records management and book keeping and provide grants to add value to cocoa and groundnuts for better price. This has increased the revenue base of SMEs from 20% in 2016 to 42 % in 2017. 3. Final Rural Development Coordination Policy document prepared with inputs from the validation for Cabinet approval 4. 600 participants had deeper understanding of how local council operates for the first time including how micro projects are distributed to the wards, the roles and responsibilities of the Paramount Chiefs, local councils and the Ward Committees, number of devolved functions to local councils (56 out of 80) and citizens monitoring mechanisms development to monitor the decentralization programme 5. 149 Paramount Chiefs developed a draft MOU on revenue mobilization and sharing, clarity of roles and responsibilities between the Paramount Chiefs, local councils and Ward Committees for effective monitoring of service delivery. 6. 10% Financial Commitment was made by the Minister of local government and rural development to support local councils to deliver on SDGs and Local Economic Development

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old

number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions

Youth Employment and Empowerment, targeting young people aged 15-35, by providing them employable skills training, in order to enhance their livelihoods
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

- 70% of young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful internship opportunities or entrepreneurial skills training who have started their business or gained jobs as a result of employment and empowerment programmes.
- # of youth benefitted by the YouthConnekt
- # of coordination actions (Minutes of coordination/collaboration meetings with MDAs and key partners) - # of capacity support provided to MoYA, NAYCOM and DYC

comment.narrative:
- 3,990 youths supported to access full time or equivalent jobs, as a result of employment and empowerment programmes
- 6 Technical Staff supported at MoYA, 12 Coordination meetings held with stakeholders, The National Youth Policy reviewed and launched in 2015, the National Youth Service scheme passed into an Act by Parliament in 2016.

1500 young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful internship opportunities, career advice and employment opportunities (disaggregated by gender); 240 youth engaged in agribusiness projects 1 5 Coordination decisions and minutes/reports b) capacity support activities provided to MoYA, NAYCOM and DYC

. 1). 3 BDS centres effectively operational in three districts have provided business entrepreneurial trainings, including the provision of grants through the Business Plan Competition (BPC) to 150 youths, (Female 66: Male 84), thereby enhancing business skills of beneficiaries. This training havel enbled them to have improved access to sustainable income generating opportunities Additionally, a total of:
2). 68 youth (9 Female 39, Male 29) have expanded their Small and Medium Enterprises (SME) as a result of the BDS intervention.
3). 38 youth businesses have been registered through the local town and city councils and some with National Social Security and Insurance Trust (NASSIT).
4). 260 existing Business Operators have received mentorship, coaching service, thus increasing their potential for business growth and diversification . 5). 384 Ebola burial team volunteers who received entrepreneurial training at the 3 BDS Centres have helped to reintegrate and empower the burial team workers, through the establishment of SMEs and/or other self employment opportunities.
7). 150 youths (68 females and 132 males) at the Obasanjo Skills and Acquisition Centre, whose skills have been enhanced through enterprise management training, have been capacitated for business expansion, self-employment and other career opportunities. 8). 4 Career Advisory and Placement Services (CAPS) Centres are providing services to an average of 100 graduates per month enhancing their employability for the labour market. Provision of advice, computer training, support services and internship will also enable young people to choose careers which are more in line with their interest and competencies. 9). 100 pupils in 5 Secondary School have received outreach career advisory services which will empower them to make realistic decisions and informed subject choices which will further help them as they transition from secondary school to higher learning and eventually for the labour ma

1) Provide internship opportunities, career advice, innovations in IT and employment opportunities to 4,935 young people (age 15-35 - disaggregated by gender)
2) Conduct 15 Coordination meetings with key youth stakeholders and provide concise reports thereafter 3) Provide capacity support to the Ministry of Youth Affairs, the National Youth Commission and the15 District Youth Councils

A total of 4,956 Youth benefited from Internship, career Advisory Service, Skills and Business training.
a. 130 Youths trained and placed in various organizations (Government, International and Privat Sector Organizations) for four month internship. This will lead to increase their knowledge and job experiences leading to permanent employment. Experience from the past shows that around 70% of the inters are employed immediately after completion of the internship in the respective organization. b. 176 (Female 79, Male 97) Youth received various business skills, planning and financial management trainings in 5 BDS. Project, 56 top business plans (Female 35 and Male;19) supported with micro grant to kick start their businesses. The trained micro and small entrepreneurs are continuously mentored to succeed in expanding and formalizing their business by registering with the relevant authorities. c. 150 Youths at the Obasanjo Skills Acquisition Centre have acquired skills training in various fields for self-employment. d. Five CAPS centers are operational and are reaching up to 100 students per Centre per month (about total of 4,500 youth) in career advice, computer training, support services and internship which is enabling young people to choose careers which are more in line with their interest and competencies and the labour market. e. Nationwide campaign on promoting youth innovation through Social Good Summit conducted. Three best innovative ideas were supported with cash prizes.
f. 15 Coordination meetings held on youth issues, with NAYCOM, MOYA and other key youth stakeholders on the implementation key youth activities such as the Youth Week Programme, the International Youth Day, Assessment of the Youth Employment and Empowerment programme (YEEP), TVET Coalition Coordination Meetings and the ‘’Review and Lessons Learned Consultancy’. Reports provided thereafter.
g. Rehabilitation of one CAPS centre completed, furniture and equipment provided through N

- 5,000 young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful internship opportunities, career advice, innovations in IT, Agribusiness and entrepreneurial skills for employment opportunities (60% Female: 40% male)
- 2,000 (Female 60%: Male 40%) benefiting from the youth Connekt Programme
- a)15 Coordination decisions and minutes/reports b) capacity support activities provided to 6 MoYA Technical Staff, 22 NAYCOM Staff and 28 DYCs

- Entrepreneurial competencies of 400 youth developed through the operation of 5 established Business Development Centers and the Obasanjo Skills and Acquisition Centre.
- SABI Centre Strengthened for Youth and Agribusiness Development for 50 youth.
- Five (5) CAPS centers are operational and able to reach up to 100 youth per Centre per month.
- 200 Graduates for Tertiary Institutions trained and placed at various institutions.
- Youth Innovation in ICT and entrepreneurship promoted.
- Implementation of youth development activities is effective and well coordinated by NAYCOM/MOYA.
- Yearly Status of the Youth Report published and other youth related publications disseminated.

description.narrative: This project seeks to support media capacity building and development in Sierra Leone. It is based on the premise that professional journalism and press freedom are critical for democratic governance and development in Sierra Leone.

title.narrative: SLE/IC/2017/012 Individual National Consultant -Evaluation of Support to Media Project

description.narrative: Capacity of democratic institutions including Electoral Management Bodies, Parliament and Media enhanced to promote democratic governance
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

- National Media Development Strategy Document - Media Reform Coordination mechanism (MRCG -SL) - Codified/draft Media Bill - Self-regulatory instruments for media (Press Freedom Charter and SLAJ Code of Practice) - Revised media education curriculum and trained staff at the Mass Communication Department, Fourah Bay College - Strengthened national media organizations (building blocks for media reform)

comment.narrative: - No National Media Development Strategy - No Codified media law and non-existent effective self-regulatory framework for media - Inadequate media coordination mechanism - Weak media organizations - Mass Communication Department, Fourah Bay College lack appropriate media education curriculum and adequately trained staff -

- Revise and support the enforcement of SLAJ code of ethics. - Enact Media bill into Media Law. - Develop and sign Cooperation agreement on Broadcast licences between NATCOM and IMC. - Log 19 community radio in the provinces on the Stirlitz (Electronic Radio Monitoring System). - Develop syllabus for core Mass Communication courses. - Develop Course Handbook. - Execute two national collaborative media activities and develop State of the Media Report.

- SLAJ Code of Ethics revised and popularised - Media Bill presented to Ministry of Information and Communication, Attorney General's office and the Law Reform Commission for final review and onward submission to the Sierra Leone Parliament. - Cooperation Agreement between IMC and NATCOM proposed. - Nineteen community radio stations logged on the Stilitz Electronic Radio Monitoring System. - Mass Communication syllabi developed for core courses - Course Handbook developed - State of the Media Report 2015 developed.

- Review and popularize Civil Libel Law.. - Develop and publish media directory. . - Organize four SLAJ complaints committee meetings. - Review and roll out strategic plan of the Independent Media Commission. - Sign MOU between IMC and NATCOM on allocation of National Spectrum. - Establish and operationalise media training database. - Sign MOU among Media Schools for the roll out of media study syllabi - Develop composite business (printing press) plan. - Develop guidelines for community radio station governance and newspaper distribution. - Establish systems and procedures on Financial management, procurement, project monitoring and evaluation - Conduct four staff sessions for MRCG Secretariat staff - Execute two national collaborative media activities.

- Civil Libel Law reviewed and popularized. - Media directory developed and publicized. - Four complaints committee meetings held. - IMC (Independent Media Commission) Strategic plan reviewed/rolled out. - Signed MOU between IMC and NATCOM on allocation of National Spectrum. - Media training database established and operationalized - MOU Signed among Media Schools for the roll out of media syllabi. - Composite business (printing press) plan developed - Community Radio Stations Governance and newspaper distribution guidelines developed - Established systems and procedures on Financial management, procurement, project monitoring and evaluation - Four staff sessions conducted for MRCG Secretariat staff on project management - Two national collaborative media activities executed - Project evaluation is being conducted.

- Eighty Percent journalists know about SLAJ New Code of Ethics - Four (4) SLAJ complaints committee meetings organised - Guidelines on monitoring of social media developed - National Spectrum allocation guideline developed - Five thematic/investigative media reports (health, Human Rights, Business and Economics) - ACJME-SL organogram and activity plan developed - Best practices on community radio stations' governance and sustainability identified and popularised. - Minimum wage enforced - a. Systems and procedures on Financial management, procurement and project monitoring and evaluation established and four staff sessions conducted for MRCG Secretariat staff - Two national collaborative media (develop State of the Media Report 2018 & MRCG SL Annual Programme Review) activities executed

title.narrative: Adaptive Capacity of Water Services to Climate Change

description.narrative: The project seeks to enhance the adaptive capacity of decision-makers in the public and private sector involved in water provision to plan for and respond to climate change risks on water resources

title.narrative: Adaptive Capacity of water Services to Climate Change_(GEF)_AWP 2016
Addendum 1 to SLE/ITB/2016/01 Supply and Installation of Automatic Hydrological Monitoring Station
Re-Advertised RFP/SLE/2015/007 ? International Firm to develop a climate resilience and emergency contingency plan for the Guma Valley Water Reservoir in Sierra Leone

RFP/SLE/2015/006 ? National Firm to undertake baseline study on public and private sector participation to manage the Exposure and Sensitivity of Water Supply Services to Climate Change in Sierra Leone (open only for locally registered firms)

description.narrative: The project seeks to enhance the adaptive capacity of decision-makers in the public and private sector involved in water provision to plan for and respond to climate change risks on water resources
populated place

activity-description.narrative: The project focuses on capacity development of institutions and communities for the supply and management of water in Freetown, Puhejun, Kambia and Kono districts

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The focus of the project is on capacity development to institutions and communities for water supply and management in Freetown and Puhejun, Kambia and Kono districts

description.narrative: populated place

activity-description.narrative: The project focuses on capacity development of institutions and communities for the supply and management of water in Freetown, Puhejun, Kambia and Kono districts

description.narrative: - # of climate change resilience plan for Guma reservoir established - # of people accessing safe water supply services at projected climate change affected communities - % change of key decision-makers with limited knowledge of climate change impacts or adaptation responses - Number of strategic documents produced and used in tackling climate change issues in the country

comment.narrative: - No climate change adaptation concerns and actions mainstreamed within the Guma Reservoir Management process - Zero additional people provided with access to safe water supply services at projected climate change affected target communities - Baseline capacity assessment to be undertaken at project onset

1. Updated Water Point and Groundwater mapping tools to adapt them to new aspects of climate changes developments within pilot communities 2. Commission a climate change resilience plan and emergency contingency plan for the Guma Reservoir 3. Construct the rooftop rainwater collection with reservoirs at Ministry of Water Resources Tower Hill Office, Ola During Children’s Hospital and the Renewable Training Centre at Sussex 4. Build and implement innovation demonstrations on spring boxes improvement in 5 demonstration sites in Kambia and Freetown 5. Drill boreholes and distribution mechanisms in twelve communities in Pujehun, Kono, Kambia and Freetown 6. Provide water storage and treatment systems to at least 20 households in Kono and Kambia

1. Updated Water Point and Groundwater mapping tools to adapt them to new aspects of climate changes developments within pilot communities - With support from the Ministry of the Water Resources, exercise was conducted to map out the nationwide water points and guide tool developed to ensure existing and any new water points are adapted to new aspects of climate changes
2. Commission a climate change resilience plan and emergency contingency plan for the Guma Reservoir - A Climate Change Resilience Plan and Emergency Contingency Plan has been developed for the Guma Reservoir. Trainings were also conducted for staff of the Guma Valley Water Company on the operationalisation of the Plan.
3. Construct the rooftop rainwater collection with reservoirs in MRW, Murray Town Hospital and EFA buildings - Design for the construction of rooftop rainwater collection with reservoirs in the Ministry of Water Resources Tower Hill Office, Ola During Children’s Hospital and the Renewable Training Centre at Sussex has been commission with construction expected to commence in 2017.
4. Build and implement innovation demonstrations on spring boxes improvement in 5 demonstration sites in Kambia and Freetown - Design for the construction of innovation facilities within existing spring boxes in Kambia and Freetown and gravity fed water in Pujehun has been commission with construction expected to commence in 2017.
5. Drill boreholes and distribution mechanisms in twelve communities in Pujehun, Kono, Kambia and Freetown - Three communities in Pujehun, three communities in Kono, four communities in Kambia and two communities in Freetown have been provided with boreholes with water distribution facilities and standing taps innovated to adapt to new aspects of climate changes projections in Sierra Leone
6. Provide water storage and treatment systems to at least 20 households in Kono and Kambia - Items (chemicals) has been provided to the Ministry of Water Resources Water storage and tre

1) At least capacities of 2 line ministries, 2 training or research centers and 2 district council to mainstream adaptation concerns within water policy and local development plans strenghtened. 2) Climate change resilient plan for guma reservoir established. 3) 15% of staff of targetted institutions aware of predicted impacts of climate change and appropiate responses. 4) 60 % of targetted stakeholders have access to relevant dessiminated adaptation experiences from the project 5) 10 new boreholes constructed in public facilities in Freetown, Kono, Pujehun and Kambia. 6) 1 gravity fed water distribution mechanisms constructed in Kono 7) Water quality training chemicals provided for treatment facilities in Freetown, Kono, Pujehun and Kambia 8) Innovative demonstration on two spring boxes improvement. 9) 3 roof top rain water collection and reservoir facilities constructed in Freetown.

1) Contracts have been signed by a consultancy firm to deliver on result one, this will be achieved in the first quarter of 2018. 2) Climate change resilience plan developed for the guma water company. 3) About 35 officers from the relevant institutions MWR, SALWACO and Guma water companies and district council leaders trained on climate change impacts, preparedness and responses. 4) Two regional workshops were held for 20 parliamentarians on adaptation experiences of the project. 5) Result 5,6 and 8 were not achieved during this period due to procurement challenges however evaluation are currently been finalised for the award of contracts. 6) Water quality training was conducted for 20 staff of the ministry of Water resources from all districts for 30 days

comment.narrative: Technocrats from MWR and EPA in Freetown but particularly regional technical staffs have extremely limited opportunity for professional updating and usually find it difficult to address newly emerging technical issues and practices into their ongoing work One of the major limitations is the lack of capacity to deal with climate risks and understandings of managing these risks in the water sector

At least capacities of 2 line ministries and 2 Districts Council to mainstream adaptation concerns within water policies and local development plans are strengthened and capacities of two research training center to deliver relevant trainings on climate change issues of are strengthened

There has been a delay in the implementation of the project due to the outbreak of the Ebola Viral Disease and a ban on public gathering and movement of people However implementation of activities will commence in earnest in the third quarter of 2015

1. Procure and install (operationalization training) meteorological and hydrological monitoring equipment 2. Re-install AMESD-PUMA e-station and upgrade SYNERGY system to support tailored weather now-cast and forecast 3. Develop in-service and on-the-job capacity development programme for Met. Technicians 4. Provide the MWR, SLMD & ONS a reliable, direct and fast data and information communication system 5. Procure and install a Television and Radio Weather Broadcast equipment for forecast dissemination 6. Develop capacity programme in hydrological modelling and sector tailored hydrological forecasting techniques and information packaging 7. Establish & operationalise a Climate Change Data Management System 8. Establish CBEWS at Bumbuna Watershed, Guma Valley and IVS Farms in Eastern Districts under a “Cash-for-Work” scheme

1. Procure and install (operationalization training) meteorological and hydrological monitoring equipment - Eight weather stations have been procured and installed that provide nationwide weather coverage for the weather information. - The National Hydrological Network has been re-established with associated equipment provided and trainings conducted for staff on the operationalisation of the network and information dissemination 2. Re-install AMESD-PUMA e-station and upgrade SYNERGY system to support tailored weather now-cast and forecast - The AMESD-PUMA e-station has been established and the SYNERGY system upgraded to aid the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Food Security in the dissemination of tailored forecast to farmers and agriculture producers. 3. Develop in-service and on-the-job capacity development programme for Met. Technicians - In partnership with EarthNetworks Inc. on the job capacity training has been provided to staff of the Met Office on handling weather stations and dissemination of tailored weather information. 4. Provide the MWR, SLMD & ONS a reliable, direct and fast data and information communication system - A Needs assessment of early warning communication network (of relevant mandated government institutions, local communities and CBOs has been conduct and communication channels between relevant mandated MDAs and local communities for dissemination of forecasting products developed. This has led to the establishment of institutional platform for collection of feedback from the community end-users on the usefulness of warning messages. A community-based communication and information sharing tool has been developed that is being pilot by CBOs as awareness raising strategy and pilot application and implementation of local level responses 5. Procure and install a Television and Radio Weather Broadcast equipment for forecast dissemination - The procurement of equipment has been deferred to 2017. However, partnershi

1) Review current legal framework supporting EWS for issuing a warning & identifying gaps and shortfalls 2) Conduct (4) refresher trainings on climate change risk assessments and mitigation measures for key stakeholders 3) Establish CBEWS at Dodo Dam (Eastern Province) and Guma Valley (Western Area) under a “Cash-for-Work” scheme and Strengthen Knowledge on Climate-Induced Risks, Emergency Preparedness and Response in the Bumbuna Watershed (Northern Province) 4) Develop and deliver in-service and on-the-job capacity development programme for 16 Met. Technicians (WMO Class IV)

1) A sustainable financial framework for the provision of Early Warning Systems on a cost recovery basis developed to help SLMD generate much needed revenues from sales of data. 2) Four refresher trainings conducted on climate risk assessments and mitigation measures for key stakeholders in the south, north, and eastern regions of Sierra Leone. 3) Drills conducted for actors of future early warning systems for youths and women in particular for the Bumbuna and Dodo hydro electric dams in affected communities(trainings conducted on technical alert jargons). 4) Seven staff of the metreological department are currently receiving the West Africa regional training center in Nigeria to on the WMO class III on weather observation and reporting. Note the target of 16 staff wasn't achieved due to funding gap.

comment.narrative:
Output 1.1: Corresponding baselines:
• 100% political parties represented in inter-party dialogues • 90% of 3,936 participants mediated electoral related disputes and advocated for violence free elections in 2012 • 100% (12) parties signed in 2012 elections • 9 out of 10 election-related disputes peacefully resolved in 2012 • 100% (All 10 political party candidates were engaged in the use of private non-state actor security personnel). According to PPRC all registered political party candidates used vigilante groups • 2 MOUs used in 2012 elections.
Output 1.2 Corresponding baselines:
• 79.6% (KAP Survey 2017 page 52 proxy indicator is awareness of the role of political parties in elections) • 30 • 4 (# recorded during the 2012 elections will be researched in the inception phase).
Output 1.3: Corresponding baseline
• 65 adjudicated in court but unresolved in 2012 elections • 31 case mediated through ADR in 2012(Start of Human Rights in Sierra Leone Report 2013) • XX in 2012 elections • No SOPS or Curricula in place, 65 cases heard in 2012 but not resolved
Output 2.1: Corresponding baseline
• 100% in the 2012 elections • None documented in 2012 • 0
Output 2.2: Corresponding baseline
• 0 (cases were not recorded in 2012) • 2 simulations for the 2012 elections
Nil
Nil

Output 1.1: Corresponding target:
• 100% of election-related contentions among political parties addressed through dialogue • 95% of participants (an audit will be conducted to establish the number that is still active) that have undergone refresher training have mediated on election-related disputes and advocated for violence-free elections • 100% (All registered political parties and APPYA and APPWA subscribe to the CoC) • 95% of all local and national level election-related disputes peacefully resolved • 50% reduction in this practice • 2 MoUs to be signed in 2018 to support peaceful and gender-based violence free elections
Output 1.2: Corresponding target:
• 85% (Midline target by December 2017); 90% (End-line target by May 2018) • 75% of targeted youth and women organizations and associations are undertaking dedicated non-violence and gender-based violence prevention activities during the election cycle) • 5 community, district, provincial and national level public and youth dialogue forums during the project life
Output 1.3: Corresponding target:
• 50 ADR and 10 court cases resolved in 2018 elections • XX in 2018 elections • At least 50% of all reported cases benefit from legal and security services in the 2018 elections
Output 2.1: corresponding indicators:
• % of security committees that are functional and responsive to election related incidence (disaggregate by type of committee i.e. DISEC, PROSEC, etc.); • % of early warning issues reported to the Situation Room that are addressed (disaggregate by type of issues and location) • Comprehensive security and communication strategies developed and endorsed by the IESPC
Output 2.1: corresponding target:
• 100% in the 2018 elections • 50% of issues to be addressed • 1 Elections Security Strategy and 1 Communication Strategy developed and endorsed"
Output 2.2: corresponding target:
• 100 • 3 Provincial simulations and contingency plans and 3 contingency plans.

Outcome 1: Political dialogue, peace advocacy and violence prevention enhanced
The project progress is on track with key milestones.
To prevent electoral related violence, the project supported Political Parties Registration Commission (PPRC) to review and validate Codes of Conduct for Political Parties, All Political Parties Youth Association (APPYA) and All Political Parties Women Association (APPWA). The Codes of Conduct will enable Political Parties, women and youths to commit to peaceful resolution of conflicts in the electoral cycle.
To promote and advocate for peace during electoral process, the project supported the National Commission for Democracy (NCD) to develop non-violence messages on peaceful elections. So far 96 jingles messages have aired and 18 open public sensitization on non-violence campaigns conducted in 18 constituencies as a means of sensitizing political parties and the electorate on non-use of violence during the electoral process. The project further supported the NCD to form and launch biweekly citizens forum for engaging national stakeholder groups and pubic mobilization and sensitization for free elections. As of mid-November 2017, a total of four (4) biweekly forums had been conducted. The project further supported the Human Rights Commission (HRC-SL) develop and disseminate non-violence messages on human rights through radio and television. At a roundtable organized by the HRC-SL and hosted by the Sierra Leone Association of Journalists, a total of forty-four media houses committed to adhere to responsible and human rights centered reporting and avoid covering hate speech during campaigns.
To enhance access to justice for right holders including women and vulnerable groups, the project supported appointment of ten High Court Judges (8 men and 2 women) by the Chief Justice to lead the special electoral courts and ensure speedy adjudication and resolving of election related incidences of violence. The project also supporte

NOTE: TARGETS FOR 2017 HAVE BEEN MAINTAINED DURING 2018

Output 1.2: Corresponding target:

• 50 ADR and 10 court cases resolved in 2018 elections • XX in 2018 elections • At least 50% of all reported cases benefit from legal and security services in the 2018 elections

1.Three(3) policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications draft and tabled before parliament 2. Woodlots established for charcoal production 3. One(1) centre of excellence for RET established 4. Five(5) sustainable charcoal production businesses developed as influenced by the strengthened policy and institutional frameworks for BET application

1. Three policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications draft and tabled before parliament - The three policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications has been enacted by parliament and endorsed by the President. 2. Woodlots established for charcoal production - 24 hectares’ woodlot have been established in three communities in Port Loko District with active engagement by the communities including management structures with women at the helm. 3.One (1) Centre of excellence for RET established -A Centre of Excellence for RET has been established at the Government Technical Institute. This Centre will serve as the main hub for training and innovation on RET 4. Five(5) sustainable charcoal production businesses developed as influenced by the strengthened policy and institutional frameworks for BET application -Training has been conducted in partnership with GERES for cook stove and charcoal production businesses enterprises in Freetown.

1. One (1) Policy that is supportive of Biomass Energy Technology (BET) applications 2. Cook stove and Charcoal Development Center (CCDC) established and functional 3. Two private sector and/or 2 local communities involved in biomass energy production 4. Fifteen (15)grants given for the production of efficient charcoal cook stoves and kilns 5. One(1) Gender sensitive capacity development and training modules for the production and utilization of certified charcoal and ICS 6. Five(5) sensitization campaigns for key value chain actors conducted 7. Forty (40) hectares of community-based agro-forestry establishment

1. Two policies developed i.e the renewable energy and energy efficiency Policies. 2. Cook stove and charcoal development center equipped with Lab for cook stove testing 3. Four(4) local communities involved in biomass energy production through the establishment of 40 hectares of wood lots. 4. Target four has not been achieved due to change in grant-loan policy at HQ. This will be pursued next year. 5. One gender sensitive training module developed for the production and utilization of certified charcoal and Improved Cook Stove (ICS) 6. Five (3) sensitization campaigns conducted for key value chain actors in the five regional head quarter towns. 7. Forty (40) hectares of community-based agro-forestry established in Port Loko and Moyamba district.

1. One (1) Policy this is supportive of BET applications. 2. One (1) Standards and certification for more efficiently produced charcoal and improved cookstoves 3. This project helps the judiciary and justice chain institutions to develop bail and sentencing regulations to ensure adequate guidance and it also supports the introduction of electronic criminal case management in the courts.

description.narrative: -WG established -WG knowledge of the process of developing sentencing and bail reforms is enhanced -Assessment completed with sex dis-aggregated data -Gender sensitive sentencing and bail policy adopted -General institutional and public awareness of sentencing policy enhanced -Guidelines completed and agreed by sentencing WG

comment.narrative: -No working group (WG) in place -No assessment been undertaken of current legislation and practice -No sentence policy in place -No guidance in place

1. Bail and Sentencing Policies that are gender sensitive and developed with full respect for the principle of participation are adopted by the mandated judicial authorities (the Rules of Court Committee)
2. The suitable and viable case management system for the Judiciary is identified and implementation commenced.

1. Based on an exchange visit with senior US Federal Judges discussing best practices, 11 national consultations ensuring outreach to the whole country on present system and practice on bail and sentencing and a desk study on bail and sentencing the Working Group has finalized draft bail and sentencing instruments that are expected to be approved in November 2016.
2. Case management needs assessment finalised and feasibility assessment of Application-based case management system finalised and presented to the Chief Justice and Senior Management of the Judiciary.
The APP-based system was identified and approved as the most suitable and sustainable case management system for Sierra Leone’s Judiciary based on the context with non-regular power and internet systems available.

1. Bail Regulations approved by the Rules of the Court Committee in May 2017 and hence binding on the Courts. Draft Sentencing Regulations finalised and awaiting the approval of the revised Criminal Procedure Act. 2. Judicial and Legal Training Institute new training curricula on ethics, judgecraft, judgement writing and bail and sentencing completed. Bail and Sentencing curricula developed for legal practitioners. 3. 550 Sierra Leone Police Prosecutors, Family Support Unit Officers and Criminal Investigations Officers trained. 350 legal practitioners, civil society representatives, including court monitors and community leaders trained on the new curricula. 4. Commenced outreach campaign on implementation of the bail and sentencing instruments through trainings of various legal practitioners. 5. Justice App implemented in 5 High Courts and 6 Magistrate Courts in Freetown, Makeni, Bo and Kenema and with expansion to include all criminal courts activated in November 2017 to be completed by January 2018.

title.narrative: Support to UN Clinic Essential Services in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Funding for the UN Clinic in Sierra Leone to maintain the required medical capacity and level of Preparedness until the end of 2015 to ensure UN system's duty of care to its personnel (and Families)

title.narrative: UN Clinic Proposal for MPTF SLE signed
40 UNDP UN Ebola Response MPTF Monthly Progress Report April 2016
40 UNDP UN Ebola Response MPTF Monthly Progress Report Feb 2016

description.narrative: MPTF support to UN Clinic in Sierra Leone to maintain the required medical capacity and level of preparedness until the end of 2015 and to ensure UN system's duty of care to its personnel and family.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Availability of non-Ebola services provided to UN personnel (with ambulance services) # of cases addressed by UN Clinic within night hours # of isolation/holding units functioning in Sierra Leone # of hours per week that clinic is open for routine care # of hours per week that clinic is open for emergencies

comment.narrative: Medical services are available during normal working hours, from 8am to 5pm 0% of cases are addressed at night hours

24/7 medical services available through the duration of the project 100% od emergency after hours cases are addressed at the UN Clinic One observation unit continue functioning in Sierra Leone 40 hours 168 hours

745 clients accessed the Clinic for services (including administrative) during the reporting period 2016. Oxygen generating capacity during the period was active, while an oxygen generating plant was installed. The project was never interrupted though there was some funding delays that caused concern with regards to renewal of staff contracts. The Clinic maintained 24/7 medical services throughout the period and a 100% emergency after hours cases were addressed at the UN Clinic, covering a duration of 40 hours for routine care and 168 hours for emergencies. All consulting, observation & emergency rooms, ambulances, holding unit and laboratory were equipped with sharps disposal containers and biohazards bags, which were collected periodically disposed off as per protocols for managing biomedical waste and safe waste by incineration at the specialized incineration unit installed at the Choithram Memorial hospital. Suspected biohazard level 4 material were adequately decontaminated and triple packed, prior to transportation and incineration.

Number of assessments/maps of existing community structures Number of health/development committees capacity strengthened Number of health infrastructure development plans developed by local authorities through participatory processes Number of community based monitoring teams Number of infrastructure rehabilitation interventions implemented in target border communities to improve health infrastructures in accordance to the plans developed Number of people that have improved access to health services Number of culturally and linguistically relevant health promotion material developed and/or modified with specific attention given to maternal, child and adolescent health priorities Number of people that have access to health promotion materials Number of outreach activities conducted by local health workforce (MCHP) Number of people accessed through health outreach activities

comment.narrative: 100 PHU structures assessed in 2016 100 VDC’s mobilised in 2016 for community led development 100 health plans developed in 2016 by 100 VDC’s 100 communities in 6 chiefdoms have implemented improvement of WASH features in 2016. This will be built upon for further investment in maternal, child and adolescent health features within the target communities 100 communities in 2016 previously undergoing the development of tailored community sensitisation material 100 communities in 2016 that have access to modified or newly disseminated health promotion materials # of PHUs in 2016 previously mobilized for the sensitization of residing communities

12 PHUs and their maternal health units assessed 12(one per health facility supported) 12 (one monitoring team per health facility supported) 12 (at least one project per community/health facility) 24,000 (2,000 people per community) 12 (at least one health promotion material per health facility) 12(at least two additional outreach activity per health facility)
Target unreached due to a prolonged period of time required to finalise the AWP.

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen the transportation capabilities of the Directorate of Drugs and Medical Supplies by providing off road 4WD mini-trucks one per each district to enable all weather access to the most remote healthcare Peripheral Health Units transporting medical supplies and logistic teams.

description.narrative: Public perceptions-based rating of NEC: • % of the public that trust the NEC • % of the public with the perception that NEC will count votes fairly

comment.narrative: Onboard CTA Secure donor funding Commence voter registration procurement
CTA onboard 22 November Agreement signed with DFID 20 December Procurement underway with first PO placed 27 December

1) Utility of the voter registration data centre (is it established, was it used to develop, print and correct voter lists, is it re-purposed for election tasks) 2) No. of people reached during voter registration campaigns through the Ward Electoral Education Committee (WEEC) Sessions using SNEC Project-supplied materials (disaggregated by location, gender and PWD status) 3) Utility of appropriate equipment and materials for in-country printing of voter lists 4) Key national-level stakeholders consulted on the workings of the results management process 5) Results Management (IT) System developed, tested and ready for deployment before the polling day 6) % of tally centres that apply the agreed results management process consistently 7) % of pre-election recommendations in the gender inclusion action plan that are addressed 8) % of stakeholder organisations that report improved inclusion of women in NEC processes 9) Domestic observers’ appraisal of women’s inclusion in the 2018 NEC processes 10) % of pre-election recommendations in the PWD action plan that are addressed 11) % of stakeholder DPOs that report improved inclusion of PWD in NEC processes (sample survey) 12) Domestic observers’ appraisal of PWD inclusion in the 2018 NEC processes 13) % of NEC electoral guidance and procedural materials that incorporate all relevant new legislative requirements 14) No. of people reached during election voter information campaigns through WEEC Sessions using Project supplied materials (disaggregated by location, gender and PWD status) 15) Timeliness of delivery of appropriate sensitive voting materials to facilitate NEC to run elections (disaggregated by type e.g. ballot papers, ink, tamper evident envelopes, etc) 16) Process established for post-election evaluation that involves key NEC stakeholders and delivers specific recommendations 17) NEC capacity to deliver voter registration and electoral process strengthened in identified areas 18) Extent of use of the M&

Voter registry established and voters cards printed and distributed Equipment proved suitable for printing polling station lists All relevant national level stakeholders consulted and process is ongoing but NEC remain committed to consultation Gender assessment framework developed and consultative workshops underway 16 PWD consultation workshops held in all regions, report developed pending validation Samples of appropriate sensitive voting materials confirmed by NEC and procurement is underway card distribution manual for the distribution of voter identity cards

1. 15,000 Voter registration Centres established 2. Voter Registration Data repurposed for election period tasks and deployed successfully 3. Voter Registration data used successfully to generate polling station lists 4. % of people increased in the voter registration than in 2012. 5. All relevant national level stakeholders consulted 6. Results IT enhanced, deployed and used effectively in 2018 elections 7. 85% of the tally centres apply the RMS process 8. 80% of pre-election recommendations addressed by March 2018 9. 60% of stakeholder organizations that report improved inclusion of women in NEC processes reached by March 2018 10. Processes established for post-election evaluation by December 2017 11. 75,000 people reached during election voter information campaigns through WEEC sessions( disaggregated by location, gender and PWD) 12. Sensitive election materials procured and fully delivered to NEC and to specifications 13. Process is used for Post Election evaluation and reflection by June 2018 14. Capacity assessed and key areas of support identified 15. Est. 100% support to the plan (June 2018)

a) To produce and launch NHDR 2018 b) Number of meetings/conferences/workshops etc on SDGs and strategic policy advice participated by Strategic Advisory Unit staff in 2016 and 2017. Baseline-1, Target-2.

a) The African Economic Outlook report and Sierra Leone Country Note 2016, successfully launched b) The African Human Development Report 2016, successfully launched c) The Country Office Economic Advisor, participated in the African Economic Conference 2016 held in Abuja, Nigeria and has shared a very informative back-to-office report that will inform critical decision for the Country Office. d) Billboards with SDGs messages at the Ministry of Finance & Economic Development and the House of Parliament, installed, which will in turn raise awareness amongst the Sierra Leonean populace.

title.narrative: Enhanced Sustainable Livelihood through Improved Natural

description.narrative: The SDG-F Sustainable Livelihoods project supports sustainable, inclusive governance of natural resources and promotes diversification of sustainable livelihood opportunities for youth and women.
Enhanced Sustainable Livelihoods through Improved Natural Resource Governance and Economic Diversification in the Kono District

In 2018, with a new Parliament in place, which is more diverse and representative, the project will push for a more strengthened parliamentary framework to improve law making, representation and oversight and thereby good governance in the country.

A new Parliamentary Service Commission consisting of the different political parties represented in the fifth Parliament will be formed. The PSC as well the new MPs will need to be capacitated in different aspects on parliamentary functioning to enable them to perform their mandated roles.
